) from Izmir. And as such, trains to Balıkesir are available from:

The station is located at Republic Square (
) on the eastern edge of downtown.  Across the highway from the station is the old bus terminal,
Balıkesir lies on the main route that the buses between
take, so has a very high frequency of buses (several every hour) from those two major centres.
Buses arriving from destinations around Turkey come into a new bus terminal (
) on Bandirma Caddesi (the old highway to Bursa and Istanbul), just inside the ringroad (

) at the extreme northern end of the city.  Just outside the terminal building is a bus stop where buses (1.35 TL) go every half hour or so into the city.  To get to the sites listed on this page, take the bus to its terminal (about 15-20 min), the
Although Balıkesir is an inland city away from the sea, you can take
and then take the train or the bus for the rest.

After the Otogar was moved out to the edge of town, the old bus terminal (
) was converted into a central station for all public transit in the city, including taxi
are clearly marked with their destination identified by district (
) and the streets on which the bus travels. All but two buses and all dolmuş cost 1.35 TL between any point on their route and

.

There are also two free bus routes that run in a circle around the city center from

. The R1 route is most useful for tourists as it passes literally every tourist site in the center, including stops right in front of or across from, Yildirim Mosque, Zağnos Paşa Mosque, and the Military Museum/Clock Tower.

The city center is also quite walkable. From
, all tourist sites are within 500 m of the square with a stroll up Milli Kuvvetler Caddesi (the street running off the Square
a sign pointing toward another city such as Edremit or Izmir) being the most direct route to Zağnos Paşa Mosque.

value: directions=located at the old town hall building
content=Museum dedicated to the fighters of Turkish War of Independence (1921-22), became to be known as “National Forces” (

). Written documents, private items and photos of the fighters, and some photos of Kemal Atatürk taken when he was in the city. Archeological artifacts excavated in the surrounding region and some ethnographic artifacts are exhibited upstairs.
directions=at the city centre, adjacent to old town hall – the Museum
of Istanbul, this clock tower was built in 1827. It took its current appearance after it was destroyed by an earthquake in 1897 and re-built.
content=Mosque Tomb of Karesi Bey and his five sons. Karesi Bey was the founder of Karesi Emirate which ruled more or less
during a period when there was no centralized, major power in Asia Minor (13th century).
content=Built by Sultan Bayezid I in the second half of 14th century.
directions=at the city centre; near Hasanbaba Bazaar
content=Built by Zağnos Pasha, grand vizier of Mehmed II period (1451-81) as a religious complex, only mosque and baths have remained to the date.
address=Akıncılar Mahallesi, Cumalı Caddesi and Tekin Sokak
directions=about 200 metres from the train station at Vasıf Çınar Caddesi and  Gazi Bulvarı

content=A clean and spacious family restaurant offering a wide variety of typical Turkish dishes, well prepared and tasty. As usual in Turkey you can select from the foods displayed inside and order-by-pointing.  There is a children's garden. They have a separate pastry shop (
), a short distance away on Yalkır Caddesi.
- Not a famous brand in Turkey but it's the best ayran you can ever drink. Can be found in almost all the restaurants or buffets in Balıkesir.

Telephone code of the city is (+90)
As the capital of one of few Turkish provinces which has a coastline on two seas, Balıkesir is around 50 km away from the seaside resort towns on both
. Two of Turkey's largest cities, the former Ottoman capital of
, "the pearl of the Aegean", lies a little further away to east and south, respectively.
